search_result.title: College football Week 2 winners and losers: Michigan, Texas lead way
search_result.text:
Michigan never stood a chance.

No. 3 Texas sailed to a 31-12 win against the No. 9 Wolverines behind 246 yards and three touchdowns from quarterback Quinn Ewers, simultaneously flashing the Longhorns' immense talent and potential while illustrating just how far the defending national champions have fallen since January.

Among the list of issues for Michigan is quarterback play. While Ewers burnished his Heisman Trophy case, former walk-on Davis Warren went 22 of 33 for 204 yards and two interceptions for the Wolverines, who have yet to crack 300 yards of offense in the first two games of this season.

That this team went into the opener with Warren is almost mindboggling given how easy it has become for programs such as Michigan to find plug-and-play quarterbacks in the transfer portal. Through two games, the senior is averaging 5.5 yards per attempt with more interceptions, three, than touchdowns. Most of his yardage Saturday came after Texas had the game in hand.

The loss snaps the program's Big Ten record of 29 regular-season wins in a row and ends what was the nation's longest active winning streak at 16 games. The last defeat for the Wolverines, against TCU in the 2022 College Football Playoff, sparked last year's historic run to perfection; this one raises some very significant questions about how far Michigan can really go in coach Sherrone Moore's first year.

The offense is already a mess bordering on a disaster, and barring any in-season adjustments or improvements stands to be a monthslong concern with do-or-die games to come against No. 14 Southern California, No. 6 Oregon and No. 3 Ohio State. It seems like a lock that current backup Alex Orji will get a chance to replace Warren, but how much difference would that make?

The Wolverines would be able to stay in the Big Ten and playoff mix with another elite defense. But Texas made this unit look underwhelming, too. The Longhorns were the first regular-season opponent to throw multiple touchdowns without an interception against Michigan since Ohio State on Nov. 27, 2021, and the first non-conference opponent to do so since Colorado on Sept. 17, 2016. Thanks in large part to freshman wide receiver Ryan Wingo's 55-yard gain, Texas also ran for 143 yards on 4.5 yards per carry with a touchdown.

Texas looks like one of the best teams in the country. Michigan resembles a team and program in transition. The Longhorns and Wolverines lead the way for the biggest winners and losers of Week 2:

Winners

Nebraska

There was never a question that Matt Rhule would win at Nebraska — the only question was how much. Beating Colorado 28-10 doesn't itself scream that the Cornhuskers are ready to make a permanent home in the USA TODAY Sports US LBM Coaches Poll; the Buffaloes are horrible and the Cornhuskers were very sloppy on offense in the second half, so it's hard to make too much of even an 18-point win. What Saturday shows is the progress from one season to the next. Last September, the Cornhuskers barely sniffed Colorado in a 36-14 loss in Boulder. A year later, this program has eclipsed the Buffaloes and left its longtime rival in the dust. In contrast to the quick-fix blueprint used by Deion Sanders that leans heavily on major roster turnover, Rhule wants to build a sustainable program that's built to last. In other words, Nebraska's program is substantially better than Colorado's today and that gap will only grow in the future.

Quinn Ewers

Ewers has to be seen as the current Heisman favorite after his performance in Ann Arbor. It's a very deep race at this early moment: Miami's Cam Ward has been terrific, Georgia's Carson Beck continues to excel and Mississippi's Jaxson Dart is off to a torrid start, so Ewers has plenty of company near the top. Already sitting at 506 yards and six scores through two games, Ewers will stay in the national spotlight thanks to games against No. 13 Oklahoma (Oct. 12) and No. 1 Georgia (Oct. 19).

Tennessee

If things were fair, dismantling No. 23 North Carolina State 51-10 on a neutral field in Charlotte, North Carolina, should thrust No. 12 Tennessee into the top 10. Where the team falls in Sunday's new Top 25 is less important than the idea that doing such a number on one of the best in the ACC shows that the Volunteers deserve to be included among the elite teams in the FBS. Josh Heupel's team are rolling early behind new quarterback Nico Iamaleava, who had 211 passing yards, 65 rushing yards and three combined scores against the Wolfpack and continues to look like one of the most promising young players in the sport. But it was the defense that delivered on Saturday, limiting the Wolfpack to just 143 yards and 1.4 yards per carry. After taking a slight step back to nine wins last season, Tennessee has a chance at putting together a special season.

Kansas State

The No. 16 Wildcats were able to escape with a 34-27 win at Tulane after the defense stepped up in the fourth quarter, breaking the 27-27 tie with a 60-yard fumble return for a touchdown with eight minutes to go and then intercepting the Green Wave in the end zone to seal the victory with 12 seconds left. This is not a win to overlook because of Tulane's place in the Group of Five: Down the line, Kansas State should earn credit from the playoff selection committee for a solid road win. Running back DJ Giddens had 114 yards on the ground and a team-best 63 yards receiving while safety VJ Payne had seven tackles, one for loss, and the game-clinching interception.

Syracuse

The Orange moved to 2-0 under rookie coach Fran Brown after a 31-28 win against Georgia Tech keyed by Ohio State transfer Kyle McCord's 381 passing yards and four touchdowns. McCord, who had 24 touchdowns for the Buckeyes last season but left after being told he'd have to compete for the starting job, now has tossed eight scores through two games. The win itself keeps Syracuse on track for a third bowl game in a row — that would make Brown the third new coach to reach the postseason in school history — but there's a question of what beating the Yellow Jackets actually means. Tech had made an early reputation on beating Florida State in Week 0, but that victory has lust some luster after the Seminoles lost big on Labor Day to Boston College.

Losers

Deion Sanders

At some point, you've got to look past all the hoopla to see the program that's actually being constructed at Colorado. After another offseason chocked with roster moves, the Buffaloes still can't block, have no running game, can't protect, can't get after the passer and are so poor defensively that keeping Nebraska off the board in the second half feels like a victory. The loss drops Sanders to 5-9 overall and just 3-9 against the Power Five, with no real reason to think that a switch can be flipped that will turn the Buffaloes into a competent group before taking on the Big 12. In fact, the Buffaloes' schedule features five teams ranked in this week's Top 25, so it can and maybe will get even worse.

Notre Dame

Northern Illinois 16, No. 7 Notre Dame 14. Given last week's confidence-boosting win at Texas A&M and the rolling hype train that had already painted the Fighting Irish as almost a lock for the playoff, this debacle qualifies as one of the worst losses in program history. Start with the postseason impact: Notre Dame has a weaker-than-usual schedule and now has to run the table to ensure a playoff berth. There's also the intense pressure on coach Marcus Freeman, who has now suffered losses to Marshall and the Huskies at home during his three-plus seasons. Again and again under Freeman, the Irish have played down to their competition; this time, doing so could very well cost Notre Dame a shot at playing for the national championship.

Hugh Freeze

Given what he took over, Freeze deserved a mulligan for last year's 6-7 finish. We'll see if that same understanding continues in 2024 after Auburn's 21-14 loss at home to new ACC member California, which kicked things off last week with an underwhelming 31-13 win against UC Davis. So how do the Tigers lose at home to a team picked to finish 10th in the ACC? Well, those five turnovers didn't help. Four came via interceptions by quarterback Payton Thorne, who has tossed at least one pick in each of his five games against the Power Four. Does Freeze need to make a change to get Auburn back into a bowl?

Arkansas

Arkansas' latest dumb, idiotic, boneheaded loss spells major trouble for embattled head coach Sam Pittman. Ahead 21-7 at halftime against No. 17 Oklahoma State — the Cowboys' points coming via a pick-six in the second quarter — the Razorbacks gave things away in the second half and fell 39-31 in double overtime. The loss is even more difficult to comprehend when you look at the box score: Arkansas gained 648 yards of offense and 33 first downs but was crippled by three turnovers and two missed field goals. Given what's ahead in SEC play, this was a game the program had to have to reach bowl eligibility; falling short of six wins would ensure that this year is Pittman's last.

Cincinnati

Another coach headed toward dire straits is Cincinnati's Scott Satterfield, who went 3-9 in debut last season and now has the Bearcats at 1-1 after a fourth-quarter meltdown against Pittsburgh. Up 27-6 with just under five minutes to go in the third quarter, UC gave up three touchdowns — the Panthers missed the ensuing two-point try on each score — and a field goal down the stretch to lose 28-27 and fall to 2-7 at home in Satterfield's brief tenure. His predecessor, Luke Fickell, went 41-10 at home from 2015-22.

Kent State

There should be no doubt over which team is the worst in the FBS. Already slotted in at No. 134 in the USA TODAY Sports NCAA Re-Rank 1-134, Kent State will be locked into last place until further notice after losing 23-17 to Saint Francis of the Championship Subdivision. Owners of just one winning season since 2017, Saint Francis is far from an FCS powerhouse. But the Red Flash were too much for the Golden Flashes, losers of 13 of 14 under second-year coach Kenni Burnes.

Alabama-Birmingham

There was something poetic about a 32-6 loss to Louisiana-Monroe and coach Bryant Vincent, who spent several years as Bill Clark's offensive coordinator at UAB and went 7-6 as the interim coach in 2022 but was passed over for the permanent position in favor of former NFL quarterback, TV pundit and high school coach Trent Dilfer. Well, that's been an ugly mess: Dilfer is now 5-9 with the Blazers after inheriting a program coming off five winning seasons in a row. Dilfer's lack of experience before taking over the program has threatened to undo all the progress UAB made after being reinstated as a program in 2017.

Defensive tackle Byron Murphy II could be the first Longhorn player taken in this spring's NFL draft but one of six in the first two rounds.

The SEC and Big Ten are the big boys in college athletics but they should think big and not overlook the small programs.

Texas has won two of the last three Directors' Cup as the nation's best athletic department and currently sit No. 3 after the fall competition.

Yeah, I think Texas is ready for the SEC

1. A super draft for Texas: You think the Texas football team was lights out in 2023? The NFL may soon agree with you. ESPN draft analyst Matt Miller wrote this week that the Longhorns would have no fewer than six Longhorns taken in the first two rounds. Six! And I’m right there with him. The “immovable” nose tackle T’Vondre Sweat will take his game to Cleveland at No. 54, Miller thinks, and even with his torn ACL, running back Jonathon Brooks is penciled in for the Packers at 58th. … Six players in 58 picks is damn impressive. Just think, if Quinn Ewers had come out, he too might have gone that high to put seven Longhorns in that hierarchy. So would sophomore offensive tackle Kelvin Banks Jr. and perhaps linebacker Anthony Hill, if they were eligible. Yes, I’d say Texas is SEC-ready.

Played In/Played Out: Promising turn for Mizzou, Wisconsin
search_result.text:
Paul Myerberg

USA TODAY Sports

USA TODAY Sports is keeping one eye on the final year of the Bowl Championship Series and another on the 2014 season, when the Football Bowl Subdivision implements four-team playoff. If the season ended today, here are three teams moving into the championship picture and three moving out.

Teams playing their way in:

Missouri. With a single win, Missouri vaults to the top of the SEC East Division and moves its way into the national championship conversation. This was no ordinary win, of course: Missouri went into Georgia and knocked off the No. 7 Bulldogs, earning its sixth win – passing last year's win total – and making a case for a sport among the top 15 teams in the country. Can the Tigers remain among the nation's elite? Remember that this isn't necessarily rarified air for Missouri, which won 48 games from 2007-11 before injuries led to a stumbling SEC debut last fall. A bigger issue is again injuries, as quarterback James Franklin could miss the remainder of the regular season with a shoulder injury. The Tigers will have to move forward against divisional foes South Carolina and Florida with backup quarterback Maty Mauk, who replaced Franklin in Saturday's fourth quarter.

Wisconsin. The Badgers might be on the outside looking in when it comes to the Big Ten title, thanks to a loss to divisional rival Ohio State, but the Rose Bowl remains a possibility – with two caveats. One, Wisconsin would need OSU to run the table, finish 13-0 and earn a spot in the BCS National Championship Game. That would then allow the Big Ten to send a second team to the BCS with an at-large bid. Two, Wisconsin would need to go 10-2 during the regular season and have the winner of the Legends Division lose at least two games during the regular season. Doable, right? After beating Northwestern 35-6, there's little doubt that Wisconsin is the second-best team in the Big Ten.

No. 21 Texas Tech. It hasn't always been pretty, but the Red Raiders head out of the second Saturday of October at 6-0, undefeated at the midway point for the first time since 2008, and one of two Big 12 teams, joining Baylor, to be perfect in conference play. It's been an auspicious debut for coach Kliff Kingsbury, who has succeeded in remaking Tech's offense – as most expected he would – and rebuilding a program's ragged sense of self-confidence. While the Raiders haven't yet tried their hand against a premier Big 12 opponent , that opportunity is coming: Tech gets Baylor, Oklahoma and Oklahoma State during a four-week span in October and November.

Teams playing their way out:

No. 10 Oklahoma. The opportunity was there for Oklahoma to put its foot down against Texas, dropping the Longhorns out of the Big 12 hunt while remaining among the undefeated teams in the FBS. Then there was the draw – last but not least – of handing Texas and coach Mack Brown a fourth loss in a row in the Red River Rivalry, extending the program's second-longest series streak under coach Bob Stoops. Think the opposite: OU stumbled, losing for the first time in 2013, and saw its spot among the Big 12's leaders go to rival Texas. While Texas lost to Brigham Young and Mississippi during non-conference play, it stands above OU in the chase for the Fiesta Bowl as the two old-schools rival reach the midway point.

No. 16 Michigan. The Wolverines had flirted with disaster before, notably against Akron and Connecticut, and seemed destined for at least one or two losses during the regular season. That Michigan's first loss came at Penn State seems particularly painful, since the Wolverines' schedule features far stiffer tests: Ohio State, for one, but also divisional games still to come against Michigan State, Nebraska and Northwestern. At this point, based on Michigan's performance through the midway point, it's difficult to imagine a scenario where the Wolverines can run the table through the Big Ten title game. But given the sloppy play on offense, the sputtering defense and cautious play-calling, can UM match last year's eight-win total during the regular season?

No. 17 Florida. Like Georgia, the Gators enter the second half of 2013 with a non-conference loss – in Florida's case, to Miami (Fla.) – and one loss during SEC play. And like the Bulldogs, UF's two losses essentially doom its chances of doing anything more than earning the SEC's at-large BCS bid, should that spot not go automatically to the second-place team in the SEC West Division. (This assumes a team like Florida doesn't beat a team like Alabama in the SEC title game, which seems like a safe assumption.) So Florida enters the second half playing for the SEC East, and can take confidence in the fact that it controls its own destiny. Unlike Georgia, Missouri and South Carolina, the Gators have yet to play any other East contender. So with the Bulldogs, Tigers and Gamecocks to come, the Gators just need to take care of business.

Paul Myerberg, a national college football writer for USA TODAY Sports, is on Twitter @PaulMyerberg.

search_result.title: Outdoors: Mastering 'Kingfish 101'
search_result.text:
Jerry Gerardi

Outdoors columnist

King mackerel, or kings as most anglers call them, Scomberomorus cavalla, have moved into area waters, providing anglers with thrilling fights, heart-stopping aerial displays, and some pretty good groceries.

Anglers have been catching them for about a month now, and the action should continue through fall until the water chills.

Fishermen have been taking kings as bycatch while fishing for red snapper and grouper. Kings are a surface fish, usually found it the top 10-20 feet of the water column.

Knowing this, anglers looking to add variety to their fish boxes have been floating out surface or flat lines with live baitfish (Spanish sardines, pilchards, blue runner, goggleye, cigar minnows, etc.) while they probed the depths for bottom dwellers.

The bite of a king mackerel is not subtle. They don’t nibble, gnaw, or suck in their prey. Better words would be crash, destroy, or annihilate.

Sometimes if a kingfish is coming up from the depths to attack a hapless baitfish swimming peacefully on the surface it will actually break the surface and shoot many feet into the air with a terrified pilchard in its toothy jaws of death.

This is called skyrocketing, or skying.

There’s nothing an angler can do until the king is back in the water and running away, at which time the hook can be set. Sometimes you get a hookup.

Sometimes you get just half a baitfish back. I hate to get the front half back. It always looks so frightened.

Kingfish have sharp teeth designed to slice and cut. You must use a wire leader, or at least 80-pound-test fluorocarbon. No. 5 or 7 browntone wire works best for me.

A foot to 18 inches will do. Also, use a black swivel to attach your line to the leader. This will prevent the fish from twisting and kinking off the leader. Hooks vary from circle, to J-style, to treble.

Some anglers add a “stinger” or free-swinging hook on a short length of leader to the eye of the main hook. The idea is to snag the king when it strikes. They work, but at the expense of tiring out the live bait.

Speaking of bait, live isn’t the only way to go. A drifted Spanish sardine or ballyhoo with three J-hooks strung tip-to-eye makes for a rig that seldom gets a short-strike. This is the rig also used drift a strip bait. A large live shrimp will take kings too.

Large swimming plugs will draw strikes from king mackerel, but they are frequently destroyed by the fish.

To counter that, use a large metal spoon. One of my favorites is a Pet spoon in Size 18 . The trick is to get it down into the water column about 10 feet. Down-riggers and trolling weights will do it.

Now for a little science. When sunlight penetrates saltwater, colors change. Because of this you should pull a red spoon from daylight to about 10 a.m., then switch to blue.

At about 4 p.m. put on a gold spoon. It all has to do with underwater visibility at different times of day, and what the fish see. If you can only troll with one color, go with gold.

Don’t have a boat to chase kingfish? Don’t worry .

Plenty of kingfish are available from Gulf and Atlantic fishing piers. Some of the best and closest to us are in Panama City Beach, Navarre Beach, Jacksonville Beach and Ormond Beach.

Techniques are somewhat different from a pier. Longer rods are needed to cast out to where the fish might be.

Live baits should be hooked through the nose or underneath and either anchored to the bottom with a 4- to 6-ounce weight, or attached to some sort of float. If you use a small balloon, tie it securely to the swivel so it doesn’t drift off when a fish strikes. Sometimes if the wind is blowing from the land to the water you can drift a live bait pretty far out.

But beware of any boats in the area. They could easily cross your line and cut it when fighting a fish.

A method that works extremely well is called “snobbling” where a dead cigar minnow or goggleye is hooked through the nose, cast out, allowed to sink a bit, then twitched back to simulate an injured fish. It’s deadly.

Spoons for pier use are limited. A 2 1/2-ounce silver Krocodile spoon works best. Cast it as far out as possible, let it sink all the way to the bottom, reel it in steadily as fast as you can (no jerking) and hang on. The strike will be sudden.

Chill kingfish as soon as they are caught. Unfortunately they are a long fish and won’t fit in most coolers and fish boxes, and you can’t cut them to fit.

Kingfish must be kept whole until landed ashore.

The solution is a soft-sided kingfish bag. Gut the fish, slip it in the bag and add ice. Or you can make your own bag with bubble wrap and binder clips.

Kingfish are usually filleted or cut into steaks. Their raw flesh is grayish, due to its high fat content.

Best prepared by broiling, grilling, baking or, especially for large “smoker” king ... by smoking. They taste like all the mackerels.

There is some concern about eating kingfish. Tests indicate high levels of mercury in the bigger fish. Guidelines call for limited consumption for normal adults, and none for small children and pregnant women.

But other studies show that free-occurring selenium in sea water bonds with the mercury and renders it harmless. Someday scientists will get their act together and come to an agreement.

All I know is that I ate kingfish once or twice a week while I was growing up with no ill effects ... except for the third ear growing out of the top of my head.

The limit on kingfish (king mackerel) in Gulf state waters (up to nine miles out) and federal waters is three per day per person, and they must be at least 24 inches long from the tip of the nose to the fork of the tail.

Also, the fish must remain whole, heads and tails intact (you may gut them) until landed ashore. This is so wildlife officials can determine the species and length of your catch.

Catch them while you can. Come winter the fish will be gone.

FISHING REPORT

Saltwater

St. George Island

Captain Russ Knapp on St. George Island (knappsgi@hotmail.com) said: “Captain Randy Peart is finding lots of white trout on the edges of the flats. Capt. Randy says use a 1/8-ounce jig head with a Gulp! shrimp.

“The Bob Sykes Cut is holding some flounder and reds. Shrimp or greenbacks will work the best. Off the beach look for nice whiting just past the surf break. Small piece of shrimp or Fishbite should do the trick.”

“Offshore, Capt. Clint Taylor is fishing live bottom 20 plus miles out and catching good numbers of mangrove and red snapper, with some gag grouper mixed in. Live bait is working the best, and be sure to bring a lot of chum.

“Capt. Clint reports the pelagics are here in force, so bring trolling gear and head for the deep water for black fin tuna, wahoo, and mahi. If you’re looking for kings they are everywhere and can be caught as close as three miles.”

Captain David Avant III on St. George Island (davidavant@aol.com; 850-228-6234) said: “The trout bite is there but you better get out early, as in before 7 a.m. or the skinny-water sport is over, then try deeper bars behind the islands. Live bait or fresh shrimp fished on the bottom in 8 feet and deeper water should produce trout, but you’ll have to move around.

“I talked to a man fishing the old St. George fishing bridge. He had had good luck at night fishing for flounder and trout using live greenback minnows. If you have a boat fish the bayside docks at night. The lighted ones have more action, but all of them are good places to toss a Cajun Thunder Float over a live pinfish.

“I particularly like the last four docks before Bob Sykes Cut. Because they’re lighted and in a prime location close to the cut. Shark fishing has also been good at night outside of Bob Sykes Cut on the outgoing tide.

“Capt. Allan Richards, aka Wooduck, has been filling limits of trout and reds but it’s been tough, he said due to low salinity, dirty water, and lack of bait.

“Some anglers fishing the beach off the second sandbar in 10-12 feet of water on the incoming tide reported a few trout, but they had been legal sized at least.

“Scallops at St. Mark’s were spotty and in deeper water. I saw only two boats out in Lanark today. I expect they found a few.”

Apalachee Bay

Otto Hough at Myhometownfishing.com (otto@myhometownfishing.com) said: “Boy, oh boy, this last weekend and first of the week was sweltering hot and humid over the Big Bend waters, but anglers were finding fish early to avoid the sauna-like conditions. The trout have moved towards the coolest waters they can find, mainly in waters 6-9 feet in depth. Outside the ‘party’ sandbar east of the St. Marks Birdrack, the trout have been hanging on the southern side, in depths of 6 feet or so out to about 9 or so feet.

“They seem to be liking the shrimp imitation soft baits like the 1/2 ounce D.O.A. and Live Target versions, though a quarter-ounce jig head tipped with a Gulp!, Saltwater Assassin or Z-Man shrimp with a tad of sweetner like ProCure shrimp has been producing well too. Some really fine trout have made the journey outside to lurk in the fringes of the Ochlocknee Shoals over the spotty bottom holes.

“Going into this three-day stretch, it looks to be another of those typical summertime fishing patterns sandwiched between the moons. High tides out of St. Marks will be happening a couple of hours or so after sunrise. There’s always hope to find some trout and reds in close early on the rising tides, but once that sun gets up by midmorning it’s time to beat a track to deeper waters for the trout. The deeper creek holes have been holding the reds.

“Along the St. Marks Refuge buoy line, the Spanish mackerel continue to prowl. Over on the flat outside Long Bar at Shell Point, the tarpon have been roaming, gulping and providing a number of anglers targeting that species with some exhilarating excitement.

“Outside, the highly ‘endangered’ (by Fed standards) red snapper was definitely in danger this past weekend, as just about every angler targeting ’em found ’em chomping. Lots of awesome fish in the 20 to 25 pound class came home to become some fine dining fare for many an angler’s family.

“The gags were not to be left out of the mix either, as they too were chomping on live bait offerings in both State and Federal waters Saturday, but only Fed waters once the clock struck midnight June 30th.

“The four-county area in State waters has closed, but will reopen Sept. 1.

“So, for now it’s a good poke out the nine-mile Federal waters. More than worth it if some quality gags are desired, though the limit is two per angler. Slow trolling the MirrOlure MR113 and Stretch 25 over live bottom is producing too. Kings have begun to wreak havoc on the baitfish pods southeast of Ochlocknee Shoals and around Marker 24. Free lining or slow trolling a frisky pinfish near one of the baitfish pods will garner attention.

“When on the Big Pond this time of year, remember to stay hydrated. It doesn’t take much time in the sweltering heat and humidity this time of year to sweat out gallons leading to heat exhaustion complications. Have plenty of water, Powerade or Gatorade iced down on board. Especially important, make certain the young anglers on board keep drinking lots of liquids. Plus, boat safely and wisely as the summertime conditions bring out the crowds to enjoy the Gulf waters.”

Capt. Dave Lear of Tallahassee said: “Hot temperatures have forced fish into summer patterns to minimize the heat. Early, late and deep is the current mantra to find trout. Reds don’t mind the hot water nearly as much, but when fishing a mixed bag it pays to max out chances.

“Depths up to eight feet are the most consistent lately. Soft-plastic jigs and shrimp lures like the DOA 1/2-ounce or Sureketch touts on a heavier jig head are scoring trout, although it requires picking through undersize specks.

“A split shiner tail (pinfish) under a cork is another summer favorite. It might also entice a passing cobia, tarpon or shark too. Early in the shallows calls for topwater plugs like Rapala Skitter Walks, Heddon Spooks or Storm Chug Bugs.

“Floating grass continues to be a problem for treble hooks, however. As an alternate, the new DOA PT soft plugs with their weedless hooks and rattle will snake right through the stringy salad.”

“Surface and slow-sinking twitch baits will fool redfish, although it’s hard to beat a weedless gold or pink Aquadream or Capt. Mike’s 3/8-ounce spoon. Work them slowly so they flutter just off the bottom and cast over oysters bars, around rock grass patches or flooded shorelines. If the reds are there, you’ll know it quick.”

“There are plenty of big adversaries if you’re so inclined. Medium-heavy tackle is necessary for cobia, tarpon and sharks. Try lime green, candy apple red or olive/pearl Gag’s Whip-it Eels for ling. A 1/2- or 3/4-ounce jig head gives good casting distance and the right sink rate. Tarpon are tarpon. Sometimes they’ll eat a kitchen sink and the next day they turn their big noses up at anything you throw.

“Early morning is the best time to look for rollers. Cast DOA BaitBusters, MirrOlure 65M twitch baits or large poppers ahead of the travel path and hope you picked the right day. Remember, tarpon must remain in the water and a $50 tag is required to submit one for a world record. Otherwise, they are strictly catch-and-release.

“Unfortunately the pre-season scallop scouting reports for the East Flats have been discouraging for bi-valve hunters. The wet spring is probably the cause. There hasn’t been any mention of scallops near Lanark, either. If you really want to go snorkeling, Keaton Beach south seems like the only early option right now. That could change as the season goes on.”

“The post 4th holiday weekend outlook looks promising, albeit with the usual chance of heat-produced thunder-boomers. Decent water flow will come mid-morning with the high tide. An average solunar feeding window will sandwich that high as the moon is up.”

Keaton Beach

Captain Pat McGriff of One More Cast Guide Service (www.onemorecast.net; onemorecast@gtcom.net; 850-584-9145) reported: “The recent rains and wind Monday stirred the water up and I had to back down off my areas to find new fish for my charter with the Zorns.

“They managed to catch nine trout and two keeper reds. Marty Zorn had top honors with the largest red. His was 27 inches long (his first-ever red). William Zorn also had his first-ever red (23 inches) and trout (19 inches) on this trip. Marty also had the largest trout, a fine 23-inch sow. We found our fish in 4.5-5 feet of water and caught the trout and reds mixed in the same two drifts. The wind was doing about 15 knots.

“We caught all our fish on live pinfish hanging 34 inches under a Back Bay Thunder. If you made a good ‘pop’ you got a hit. Essential to make a loud noise with your Thunder due to the stained water and the wind.

“If the current trends hold, expect to need your Original and Back Back Bay Thunders to raise fish this weekend. Find the correct stain and you should find the bite. I saw Pete and Kay Giddens of Ocilla, Ga., and they had caught their limit of trout and reds both Saturday and Sunday. They were fishing live pinfish under Back Bay Thunders also.”

Steinhatchee

Kristin Skipper at Sea Hag Marina in Steinhatchee (352-498-3008) sent photos of scallops, scallops, and more scallops. Fish-wise, there were several big kingfish, red snapper, gag grouper, and a large cobia.

Freshwater

Lake Jackson

Otto Hough at Myhometownfishing.com (otto@myhometownfishing.com) said: “Mother Nature over the past weekend was somewhat kind to Lakes Jackson, Carr and Iamonia by dumping numerous afternoon thunderboomers over the lakes.

“Still, with all the showers the main pool at Jackson only hopped up seven inches. When looking back to this time last July at the lake level, it’s gonna take another 17 inches of new water to get the lake level up. Even then, the lake will still be sitting below normal full-pool depth.

“For those anglers fishing out of kayaks, canoes, jon boats and small Gheenoes, the bass have been cooperating early morning and late afternoon. The larger jon boats and Gheenoes have finally gotten enough water to launch out of Sunset Landing and the US-27 N landings.

“Most anglers with motors have been working the south end of the lake. The north end has pretty much begun to fully top out with coontail mats, leaving a goodly amount of lake for kayakers to traverse.”

search_result.title: 101 things to do in Montana
search_result.text:
Tribune Staff

Whether you live in Montana and are looking for a road trip, or visiting the state from afar, we have 101 outings for you to put on your bucket list.

IN AND AROUND GREAT FALLS

1 River's Edge Trail

As the Missouri River "meanders through Great Falls, sheltering waterfowl and encouraging other wildlife — and human recreation — along its banks," so does this nearly 60 miles of paved and graveled pathways for walking, running, skating and bicycling. A result of a cooperative partnership by the city of Great Falls, Cascade County, Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks, Department of Transportation, PPL Montana and the volunteer trail advocacy group, Recreational Trails Inc., it is one of the urban delights of Great Falls that blends the city with its rural surroundings. Some of its "splashy features include Black Eagle Falls, Rainbow Falls, Crooked Falls, Ryan Falls (the "great falls of the Missouri") and Morony Falls, outdoor art and memorial benches and tables and picnic shelters.

In 1990, Recreational Trails Inc. formed to help forge the riverside route, which grows each year with new places and trails to explore. The paved, wheelchair-accessible trail runs along the south shore of the river, from Oddfellows Park, which is near the Warden Bridge on 10th Avenue South, past Broadwater Bay, Mitchell Pool, Gibson and Elks Riverside Parks, Black Eagle Falls, the Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center, Giant Springs Heritage State Park and Rainbow Falls to the Crooked Falls Overlook. The asphalt ends there, but the trail doesn't. A dirt trail stretches along the cliffs another three miles to Cochrane Dam.

East of Great Falls, the North Shore Trail follows along Cochrane, Ryan and Morony reservoirs. The trail begins at the end of Rainbow Dam Road and includes gravel and single track segments totaling more than 13 miles. A single-track trail now runs between Rainbow and Morony dams, and a trailhead has been established at Rainbow Dam. An expert single-track trail between Ryan and Cochrane dams provides an exceptional way to explore the river canyon east of town. Interpretive signs describing the ecology of the area have been provided by the Cascade Conservation District and the Missouri River Council, and QR Code signs along the trail make information about the trail and dams available to smartphone users.

The Montana Department of Transportation has completed the design of the Sun River Connector Trail to extend a separated bike and pedestrian connection along Country Club Blvd., between the west approach of the Warden Bridge and 6th Street Southwest, and construction will begin in 2016. This summer's improvements will include a paved loop from Heritage Park down to Giant Springs, a new trail between the Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center and Giant Springs and the opening of a 2.1-mile loop linking the Heritage Center, Giant Springs and Heritage Park. Paving will be done to the parking area at Bay Drive, and United Materials will be redoing the shoulders along the trail from 15th Street to Giant Springs.

Summer 2015 activities include Audubon West Wednesday Walks for bird watching along the river and on Sacajawea Island, Cochrane Dam crossings on July 11 and Aug. 22 and a number of "fun runs" and mountain bike activities. For details call 788-3313 or read more about the trails at www.thetrail.org.

2 The C.M. Russell Museum

Visitors from all over the world enjoy the Great Falls museum named after the famous cowboy artist who adopted Great Falls as his home more than a century ago. They also can enjoy the Russell Rider Sculpture Garden, a place "families can come, free of charge, all four seasons" to picnic, roam the garden and appreciate wonderful art including five major bronze pieces. Five galleries have been installed to showcase the "astonishing depth and range" of Russell's art, which ranged from paintings and sculpture to illustrated letters and pen-and-ink drawings during his lifetime (1864-1926). The museum has some 2,000 Russell artworks, personal objects and a "permanent collection of more than 12,000 objects" including works of such well-known artists as O.C. Seltzer, Winold Reiss, J.H. Sharp and Frank Tenney Johnson.

Don't miss "The Bison: American Icon, Heart of the Plains Indian Culture," the most ambitious permanent exhibition ever displayed at the C.M. Russell Museum. With about 500 artifacts and a thundering buffalo diorama that shakes as you walk over it, the $1.5 million exhibition is a fitting subject because three-quarters of the Russell Museum's entire collection of paintings and sculpture involve Indians and bison. The "Browning Firearms Collection" of rifles, shotguns and handguns surveys the significant developments made by the Browning, Winchester and Colt companies. New this season is "Harmless Hunter: The Wildlife Work of Charles M. Russell," runs through Sept. 13, and "focuses for the first time on Russell's painting of wildlife."

Right beside the museum is Russell's Log Studio, built in 1903. The artifacts in it belonged to Russell and were used for reference in his artwork. The Russell home next door was built in 1900 under the supervision of his wife, Nancy. During the summer, the museum, located at 400 13th St. N., is open Tuesday to Sunday. Museum hours are 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., the cabin studio is open 10 a.m. to 4:45 p.m., and the home is open 11 a.m.-4 p.m. Admission is $9 for adults, $7 for seniors, retired military and schedule tour groups, $4 for students and is free for active military and kids under age 5. Call 727-8787, or visit www.cmrussell.org.

3 Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center

The Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center is nestled into the bluffs of the Missouri River overlooking a section of river where the famed explorers portaged two centuries ago to avoid the nearby waterfalls. Black Eagle Falls, the uppermost of the five falls, is visible from the big windows of the interpretive center. Outside, four pedestrian trails connect the interpretive center with Giant Springs Heritage State Park, and a bicycle-pedestrian trail connects the interpretive center with the River's Edge Trail via a tunnel beneath Giant Springs Road.

Inside the center, the exhibits are educational and interactive. The ground floor includes the ornate Compass Rose, with a list of private contributors who helped finance the original construction. Only half of the construction cost was funded with federal money. Pictographs tell the explorers' story in Indian drawings. Grabbing the most attention as visitors enter the center is a striking life-size diorama of buckskin-clad explorers hefting a 30-foot canoe up a ravine in their portage around the falls. The exhibit stretches two stories and is framed by vast windows overlooking the Missouri.

The center "imparts to the public a personal sense of President Thomas Jefferson's vision of expanding America to the west; it inspires awe and awakens curiosity toward the challenges faced by the expedition as they portaged the great falls of the Missouri river and explored the 'unknown'; brings to life the daily experiences of the expedition and the environment and native peoples of the 'uncharted West'; and celebrated the indomitable spirit of human discovery we all share," according to the center's mission statement.

The 26th Annual Lewis and Clark Festival is taking place June 19-21 and promises to deliver participants "back to ways of the Lewis and Clark Expedition and life out on the open frontier of the West." This special event includes historical programs, children's activities, Native American cultural programs, artisans and local craftspeople and a variety of local food vendors.

On Fridays beginning June 26, "Riverside Voices," staff of the center and guest presenters, offer evening programs in the amphitheater on the bluffs overlooking the Missouri River or in the indoor theater. Topics include medicine on the expedition, the boats used in the journey, changes in the river since the exploration and more Lewis and Clark history and related subjects. A "Star Party Extravaganza" for learning about our night sky with the Central Montana Astronomy Society, is Sept. 25 in the center's parking lot.

Summer hours are 9 a.m.-6 p.m. daily. Costs are $8 for adults and free for those 15 and younger. Federal Interagency Annual, Senior, Military and Access Passes are honored for free entry.

Contact Information: 4201 Giant Springs Road, Great Falls, MT 59405. Phone: 406-727-8733.

4 Alive @ Five

If you enjoy live music, street dancing and great food, friends and fun, plan to attend Alive @ 5, a "big city experience in the heart of Great Falls." Every Thursday from June 11 through Aug. 6 (except for July 30), one designated area of downtown comes alive with "the finest street music tradition" of food vendors, liquid refreshments, live music and activities for children. The June 18 date was reserved for "Taste of Great Falls," a sampling of fare from local restaurants, and Aug. 6 also will be a fundraiser for Roberts Park. The events are held from 5 to 9 p.m. Call 406-453-6151 or visit downtowngreatfalls.net for more information.

5 Giant Springs State Park

First documented by the Lewis and Clark Expedition in 1805, Giant Springs is one of the largest freshwater springs in the world. This is also the site of the Roe River, once listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the world's shortest river. Giant Springs flows at a measured 7.9 million gallons per hour or 156 million gallons of water per day. The water stays at a temperature of 54 degrees and has been carbon dated to be about 3,000 years old. More than a quarter of a million lovers of nature visit Giant Springs Heritage Park each year. Many come to marvel at this remarkable feature, or to view the 80-plus species of birds, mammals and reptiles. On any day you may find bicyclists, fishing enthusiasts, photographers and many others; some come to visit the nearby Rainbow Falls Overlook, the visitor center and the fish hatchery.

The fish hatchery program raises from 700,000 to 800,000 fish annually. They are then distributed to areas in central Montana from the Canadian border to the Wyoming border. A group picnic site is also available. The Fish, Wildlife and Parks visitor center (right across from the roadway from the springs) features taxidermy mounts of grizzly and black bears, educational features on fish and bird recognition, wildlife photographs, and a mini-theater that shows wildlife videos. Pets on leash are welcome.

Events at the park include ranger talks dealing with the wildlife of the area, bird strolls and kids activities. Check the website at stateparks.mt.gov for specific dates. Concerts will be held in the park on July 12 and Aug.9, and visitors may want to plan to attend Movie Night in the Park on Aug. 21 or the Fall Family Fest on Oct. 17.

Located off U.S. Highway 87 in Great Falls, then a mile east on River Drive to Giant Springs Road. The park is open year-round from are 8 a.m. to sunset; the visitor center is open Monday to Friday, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission is free for vehicles with Montana plates and $6 per vehicle for those from out-of-state.

6 Paris Gibson Square Museum of Art

One of Great Falls' oldest and most recognizable landmarks, the Square, at 1400 1st Ave. N., has served as a center for learning and growth for more than 100 years. Built of native gray sandstone, the structure was completed in 1896 and served for 34 years as a high school and for 45 years as a junior high. "Art is for everyone" is the premise of the Square; since 1977, it has provided a "dynamic program of exhibitions, classes, lectures, tours and performances designed to nurture the region's creative spirit."

The "Val Knight Retrospective," a new permanent exhibition has been added to the Square and includes 25 remarkable works done from the 1960s to the 1990s by the late Great Falls artist in a variety of media that includes encaustic paintings, ceramic figurines and graphic drawings. Other summer exhibitions include "The Blind Men & the Elephant: Drawings by Steven Glueckert" until Aug. 1; "Artist in Residence – Danielle O'Malley" until Sept. 1; "Alas, the Pelicans: Randi O'Brian" until Sept. 11; and Manel Alvares: A Journey" July 28-Oct. 16.

Home-style cooking with an international flair is the forté of Café Paris, which is open for two lunch services, at noon and 12:30 p.m., on Wednesdays and Thursdays of each week. Lunches are priced at $15. Reservations are required.

Admission is free as a gift to the community from Farmers Union Insurance. Open Monday to Friday, 10 a.m.-5 p.m., Tuesday, 5-9 p.m. and Saturday, noon-5 p.m. Closed Sundays, July 4 and Labor Day. Call 406-727-8255 or visit www.the-square.org.

7 The History Museum

"When you enter the History Museum, you walk back in time in North Central Montana!" promises the 47,000-square-foot museum at 4223 2nd St. S., in the old Northern School Supply building. Permanent exhibits on Cascade County and northcentral Montana are featured, and temporary exhibitions on topics ranging from Montana history to local art augment the collection. Current exhibits include a salute to the history of nursing at the Columbus Hospital from 1900 to 1968 and a new exhibit centered around the history of downtown Great Falls. Permanent exhibits include the Bovey carriage, models of the Opera House and Park Hotel and displays on the Ozark Club and Native Americans. As well as "Under the Big Stack: the Great Falls Smelter" about the Anaconda Copper Mining Company's history in Great Falls.

The Museum also houses the Archival Research Center on the second floor, a gift shop and space available for special events. Museum hours are Tuesday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., and by appointment on weekends. Admission is free with donations welcome. Call the History Museum at 452-3462 or visit www.thehistorymuseum.org.

8 Children's Museum of Montana

The Children's Museum is a wonderland where "please touch" is one of the most important rules. The museum, which turned 14 in February, is an educational and community resource "dedicated to the notion that children learn best by doing." Exhibits and programs focused on history and culture, science and technology, health and nutrition, visual and performing arts and regional culture offer a unique hands-on adventure.

Located at 22 Railroad Square, the museum is just northwest of the Civic Center and within a Frisbee flip of Gibson Park. Housed in the historical railroad district, the 1913 museum building originally was a food brokerage that unloaded supplies from railcars on the adjacent tracks.

Cost is $4 per person and free for children under 2; memberships are available starting at $65 a year. Groups of 10 or more are always welcome with 24 hours notice; the cost is $3 per child in the group, and one adult must accompany each five children. Call 452-6661 or visit www.childrensmuseumofmontana for current programs.

9 Other Great Falls Experiences

Great Falls boasts many other museums and art galleries that work well together as a group. They showcase local artists and an impressive array of the city's history and culture including:

The Great Falls Public Library houses the Great Falls Genealogy Society on the third floor. Since 1975, the society has encouraged an active interest in genealogy and preserving genealogical records that could help patrons learn about ancestors in this region. It's staffed entirely by volunteers. The library is open Tuesday to Saturday, 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Call 727-3922 or visit www.gfgenealogy.org.

The mission of Galerie Trinitas, located adjacent to the chapel on the University of Great Falls campus, is to preserve the art of Sister Trinitas Morin and to promote "an appreciation for religious art." A Sister of Providence, she "created art for the chapel, friends and for special occasions." Some of her pieces are currently in the traveling art show, "Women's Spirit, Catholic Sisters in America." Hours are noon-3 p.m., Tuesday and Thursday, or by appointment by calling 791-5367. Admission is free.

The Malmstrom Air Force Base Museum at the east end of 2nd Avenue North, has displays that depict the history of Malmstrom Air Force Base from its beginning as a B-17 training base to the largest Minuteman ICBM missile field in the world. Public passes are available at base visitor center at the 2nd Avenue North gate. The museum is free and open Monday-Friday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Call 731-2705 for additional/weekend hours, special arrangements or for more information or visit them online at www.malmstrom.af.mil/library/malmstrommuseum.index.asp.

The Ursuline Retreat and Conference Centre and Museum, located at 2300 Central Ave., has transformed from a solely educational institution to its present function as a retreat and meeting center and a museum of antiques and Indian artifacts while still providing learning experiences through a child care and pre-school. The building, placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1991, opened its doors in 1912, and the fourth floor archive preserves the documented history of the Ursuline Sisters in Montana and the western states. Hours are Monday-Friday, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. with guided tours available by appointment. Call 452-8585 or visit www.u-centre.com.

Grab your camera, and hop on! The owners of the Great Falls Historic Trolley, the Downtown Great Falls Association, now offers tours of the scenic and historically and culturally rich Great Falls seven days a week beginning June 1 and ending Sept. 1. The "historic" two-hour tour is $22 for adults and $5 for children, and departs from Paris Gibson Square Monday to Saturday. at 10:30 a.m. The "Urban Adventure" one-hour tours are $15 for adults and run Friday to Sunday. at 1:30 p.m., and Monday to Saturday at 4:30 p.m. Choose a package tour or customize your very own by calling 727-8255. And for vacation information, tours and shuttles throughout central and northcentral Montana, contact Tour de Great Falls at 771-1100 or 888-707-1100.

On the first Friday of each month, downtown galleries, museums and businesses in Great Falls stay open late to welcome guests who can take a peek at area artists' latest works in the First Friday Art Walk. Guests often are treated to drinks, food and live music at the various sites. Check the Tribune's "Hot Ticket," published each Friday, for details about that week's participating artists.

10 Community Rec Center

The Rec Center offers summer camps, after-school programs, exercise rooms and dance classes, all in a safe environment. 11 Riverside Rail Yard Skate Park

Great Falls is the envy of skateboarders all across the Big Sky with its 27,000-square-foot Riverside Rail Yard that is "considered one of the top five skate parks in the Pacific Northwest." The park features a series of bowls, including one that's 9 feet deep, a fullpipe, halfpipes, a clamshell and a street course with ledges, rails and stairs. There also are handicapped-accessible restrooms, a plaza with picnic tables for spectators, a drop-off area and nearby parking. And the best part? Four city-run aquatic facilities offer lessons and programs year round:

Electric City Water Park can be found at River Drive and 1st Avenue South. Beat the heat with as many ways you can get wet, including body-boarding on the "Flow Rider" where 36,000 gallons of water rushes through every minute, riding the "Power Tower Plunge" and ending up in the "Lazy River," which circles a quarter-mile around the "Flow Rider" or swimming in "Mitchell Pool," Montana's largest public heated outdoor pool. Paris Gibson, the founder of Great Falls, hoped to launch a metropolis. He demanded parks, and that's what we got. His namesake is the centerpiece of the park system. Located at Park Drive and 1st Avenue North, Gibson Park features a duck pond, flower gardens, a walking path, basketball courts, restrooms and a playground. 14 Pacific Steel and Recycling Trailside Dog Park

An attractively fenced and landscaped area where dogs can "run free and play 'off leash' with their canine and human friends," the dog park, located at 800 River Drive North alongside River's Edge Trail, was opened July 15, 2009. The site, at 342 Ulm-Vaughn Road, consists of a mile-long sandstone cliff, remnants of drive lines and up to 18 feet of compacted buffalo remains as well as "expansive panoramic views" of the Rocky Mountain Front, the Missouri River valley and characteristic buttes and grasslands of the High Plains. 18 Great Falls Golf Courses

Great Falls has two municipal golf courses where the motto is "We'll work for you, so you can come out and play. Eagle Falls, adjacent to Legion Park at 25th Street and River Drive North, and Anaconda Hills, a short, hilly course in Black Eagle on the north side of the Missouri River, 2400 Smelter Ave. Both courses offer driving ranges as well as full pro shops and concessions. 19 The Great Falls Dams

The beautiful waterfalls east of Great Falls now are mostly covered by a series of hydroelectric dams. But glimpses of the falls so famously journaled by Lewis and Clark remain, especially when water is running high on the Missouri. Visitors have several opportunities to view these dams. Perhaps the easiest is Black Eagle Dam, which can be seen close up on the River's Edge Trail or from an overlook on River Road. Just downstream, Rainbow Dam has also been offering beautiful views since 1910 and has undergone a construction project increasing its generating capacity by 70 percent. Between these two is Cochrane Dam, part of the Great Falls Portage National Landmark, which produces 64 megawatts of electricity. Ryan Dam, the original "great falls of the Missouri," is an especially fun destination. A suspension foot bridge leads to an island from which visitors can climb to an observation point and get a full-on view of the dam. The island has a picnic and cooking area very popular with families. Morony Dam is 15 miles northeast of Great Falls. It's classified as a "run-of-river" project because it can generate electricity using the water that flows down the river without need to store additional supplies. Boaters, hikers and fishermen should call 454-5840 for current trailhead, boat launch and parking closures.

20 Black Eagle Memorial Island

Black Eagle Memorial Island opened to the public for the first time in 2005. Located just below Black Eagle Falls, the man-made island was created from material dredged out of the tailrace below the Black Eagle Dam's generation station. In the past, it was used as a parking lot for smelter workers at the former Anaconda Mining Co. complex. Today the area features a restored truss bridge, exceptional stone walls, a launch for non-motorized boats and an interpretive viewing plaza below the falls. The area is open for hiking, biking, kayaking, canoeing and fishing and is part of the new River's Edge Trail section that links West Bank Park to the island.

21 Missouri River Breaks National Monument

On a topographical map of Montana, the Missouri River Breaks look like a crumpled brown grocery bag extending west to east along the Missouri River from Fort Benton to Fort Peck. The Arrow Creek Breaks and the Musselshell Breaks contribute to the larger geographic area from the south. The Breaks, located in northcentral Montana, offer some of the finest recreational opportunities in the entire state, from river floating to hiking to hunting to horseback riding.

On the ground, the Breaks consist of rough ridges separated by steep — sometimes almost vertical — coulees. The vegetation consists of scattered Ponderosa pine, juniper, Douglas fir and mixed grasses growing in a shale/gumbo soil type. While not the most hospitable region for humans, the Breaks provide suitable habitat for an impressive list of wildlife species.

The Breaks mean different things to different people. It is defined, in part, by the history of Lewis and Clark, as a sanctuary for desperados staying a step ahead of the law and as a source of hope and inspiration for several generations of homesteaders. Some enjoy the remote area mostly for the solitude and recreational opportunities provided by the Upper Missouri River, Fort Peck Reservoir and a mixture of public and private lands. Others see the Breaks as a source of grass for livestock, natural gas, timber products and other vital pieces of our economic puzzle.

In 2001, a portion of the public land in the Breaks managed by the Bureau of Land Management, roughly 375,000 acres, was designated as the Upper Missouri River Breaks National Monument.

U.S. Highway 87 accesses the western portion of the monument at Fort Benton. On the eastern edge, U.S. Highway 101 crosses the monument and the Missouri at the James Kipp Recreation Area, and Montana Highway 236 also provides access through Lewistown, Winifred and Big Sandy.

There are no motels, service stations or restaurants in the interior of the Monument. The Missouri Breaks Interpretive Center in Fort Benton is open 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday to Friday Call 622-4000.

22 Monarch and Neihart

An hour's drive from Great Falls, these neighboring mountain towns are located in a historic mining district. The mines are closed, but the surrounding mountains are open to fun. Local creeks offer excellent fishing. There are scores of trails and backcountry roads to explore on foot, mountain bike or all-terrain vehicle. Check at trailheads for info on motorized access. 23 Sluice Boxes State Park

Just south of Belt, where Belt Creek slices out of the Little Belt Mountains is an area of soaring limestone cliffs and precipitous ledges, the Belt Creek Canyon and Sluice Boxes State Park. Rich in history and geologic features, the park provides excellent hiking and viewing of abundant wildlife in a wide range of habitats from shaded rock walls and miniature waterfalls to open, sun-baked slopes covered in prairie grasses. Enjoying the park, however, is not for the faint of heart. Because the train bridges were removed, hikers must ford the creek. That's nearly impossible during high water, so hiking in the Sluice Boxes is limited to the low-water season — usually mid-July through September. The creek is spring-fed and cold. Backcountry camping is allowed with permit year-round. The only facilities are the parking lot, vault toilet and the trail which follows an abandoned rail grade. Call 454-5840 or visit stateparksmt.gov/sluice-boxes.

24 Fort Benton's Riverfront

The historic community of Fort Benton, 42 miles north of Great Falls, boasts a stunning setting on the banks of the Missouri River. The site of a pre-Civil War trading post and key economic point during the "steamboat era," the town is the water gateway to the Missouri Breaks National Monument and a popular launch site for rafts and canoes. Reconstruction of three buildings of the fort is taking place; the Northeast Bastion and Blockhouse are now historically accurate. A heroic-sized statue of explorers Lewis and Clark overlooks the river along a scenic walking path. Another statue immortalizes Shep, a legendarily faithful dog. A walking bridge spans the river and offers benches for rest and reflection. There's lots to do elsewhere in town, which has two museums and a historic restored hotel, the Grand Union, which boasts a fine restaurant. From June 26 to 28, visitors may experience Montana's premier small town festival. In celebration of Chouteau County's 150th birth, the theme this year is "Footsteps Through Time." Call 750-2918.

25 Havre Beneath the Streets

The Historical Underground Tour is a recreation of Havre's history. When fire destroyed most of Havre, business owners moved underground to carry on their business until the town could be rebuilt. Step back in time as much as 100 years, into the Sporting Eagle Saloon, a turn-of-the-century honky-tonk where cowboys gambled, kicked up their heels and drank good old-fashioned frontier rot-gut. Saunter along the streets beneath Havre and see an opium den (one of three known to have existed in the early days), a Chinese laundry, an ethnic restaurant, and, of course, a bordello.

Tours are available during summer months Monday through Sunday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. with the last tour beginning at 3:30 p.m. Reservations are recommended; the ticket office is at 120 3rd Ave., south of Norman's Ranch Wear. Prices are $14 for adults, $12 for seniors 65 and older and $8 for children ages 6-12. Special evening and group tours are available upon request. Call 265-8888 for information or visit the Havre Chamber of Commerce, 518 1st St. See www.havremt.com.

The Havre Railroad Museum at 12 Third Ave., the newest museum in Havre and a must for railroad buffs, offers a brief history of the 10 different railroads that rolled through Havre in the past. Included are a relay office recreation, reference library, original hand push carts, a complete model railroad and more. It's free and open 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily. Call 265-8888 or visit www.ultimatemontana.com.

26 Wahkpa Chu'gn Buffalo Jump

For an up-close look at a historic Native American site, visit the Wahkpa Chu'gn Buffalo Jump overlooking the scenic Milk River on Havre's western edge. Take a one-hour walking tour for a close-up look at the best-preserved bison kill and campsite in this area of the plains. The Brick Mural is now complete in the shadow of the Bear Paw Mountains. The site is non-sterile, so visitors may handle certain artifacts. Open June 1 to Labor Day from 9 a.m. to 4.p.m. Tours are usually available "on demand." Call 265-6417 or visit www.buffalojump.org for more information.

27 Fort Assiniboine Historic Site

Fort Assiniboine Historic Site, located 6 miles southwest of Havre on Highway 87, was constructed in 1879, and became the largest military fort west of the Mississippi River. The post had 104 buildings and was contained within a 40-mile-long by 15-mile-wide military reservation. Several of the original buildings still stand. It became a state agricultural experiment station in 1911 and is now the home of Montana State University's Northern Agricultural Research Center. The primary mission of the fort's garrison was to prevent attacks from the some 5,000 Lakota Sioux Indians led by Sitting Bull, and other chiefs who had fled to the safety of Canada after the Battle of the Little Big Horn.

The fort served as a base for patrols along the Canadian border and the Milk River Valley. Fort Assiniboine became the state's military headquarters, with the responsibility of maintaining control over the Blackfoot Confederacy and other northern Montana Indian reservations. The most famous soldier to serve at the fort was John J. Pershing, who was assigned to the post in 1896. He commanded H Troop, the black "Buffalo Soldiers" of the 10th Cavalry. The Fort Assiniboine Preservation Society offers summer tours from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., Mon.-Fri., and by appointment for the weekends. For additional information, call 262-7656.

The Northern Agricultural Research Center will celebrate its 100th anniversary with several events including the annual field day and tours July 1 with the first tour beginning at 1 p.m. The new office building will be dedicated, and agri-business awards presented. Call 265-6115.

28 Charlie Russell Chew Choo

Experience the beauty of rolling hills, vast ranch lands and breathtaking sunsets from the comfort of a vintage train; possibly masked bandits may even stage a hold-up when least expected. Now beginning at Kingston Junction, near Lewistown, and crossing three trestle bridges on its route to Denton and back, the 3.5 hour trip offers includes a full course prime rib dinner, dessert, no-host cash bar and musical entertainment. 29 Freezout Lake

Freezout Lake and its surrounding 11,466 acres, is a prime hot spot for bird lovers in Montana. In spring, hundreds of thousands of migrating snow geese stop at Freezout for a rest before flying north to Canada's Alberta and Saskatchewan, and then to nesting grounds at the Arctic coast. Park officials recommend viewing from sunrise to 10 a.m. and from 4:30 p.m. to dusk in early March, but wildlife viewing is available year round. For a more enjoyable experience, stay for a maximum of 14 days. Bring binoculars or telescope, a light lunch and warm clothing. Call 467-2646 or 467-2488.

The 26th annual festival is scheduled for Sept. 12 in Lewistown. The chokecherry, a small, maroon-colored, tart fruit that grows wild in Montana, will reign supreme on the first Saturday after Labor Day. The festival traditionally is attended by close to 4,000 people. The day starts with the Kiwanis Club serving an outdoor breakfast at Main Street and Second Avenue. 32 Blaine County Wildlife Museum

Located at 417 Indiana St., in the Chinook downtown business district, the project began in 1991 when the Blaine Theater building was donated by the Blaine Bank of Montana. It features more than 200 animal displays set in natural habitats and a gift shop with works from Montana artists, carvers and taxidermists. Museum hours are 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday through Saturday, and 1-5 p.m. Sunday, from June 1 through Aug. 31. Admission is $6 for adults and $4 for students. Call 357-2385 or visit www.bcwildlifemuseum for more information.

33 Bear Paw Battlefield

Fifteen miles south of Chinook on Route 240 is the battlefield that commemorates the end of the Nez Perce War of 1877. The flight of the Nez Perce, led by Chief Joseph from Army soldiers, took them from Oregon, through Idaho, into Montana and almost to the Canadian border before they were defeated. Here the tribe split up, with some heading to Canada and others to Nebraska. The Nez Perce ceased fighting at Bear Paw on Oct. 5, 1877, and Chief Joseph gave his immortal speech, "From where the sun now stands, I will fight no more forever." The battlefield is open daily year-round during daylight hours but closed for lunch from noon to 1 p.m. Visitors may walk a self-guided 1.25-mile interpretive trail of moderate difficulty and are encouraged to visit the Blaine County Museum at 501 Indiana St. in Chinook and see the audio/visual presentation "40 Miles to Freedom" before touring the battlefield. There are no fees. Call 406-357-2590.

34 Benton Lake National Wildlife Refuge

Located at 922 Bootlegger Trail and administered by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Benton Lake National Wildlife Refuge is a 13-square-mile oasis of grasslands and wetlands lying within a sea of agriculture. Mountain ranges surround three sides, forming a backdrop to a scene that reminds visitors of the days when the entire prairie-wetland ecosystem was alive with thousands of different birds. Benton Lake was created thousands of years ago by the continental glacier, and the area was excluded from homesteading in 1885 in order to provide an irrigation district. Animals abound in the refuge and include water birds such as ducks, Canada geese, snow geese and tundra swans. Also common are sightings of dozens of species of mammals, including mountain cottontail, American badger, striped skunk and long-tailed weasel. Ten numbered signs along the Wildlife Auto Tour correspond to a map provided at the information kiosk at the beginning of the drive, helping visitors reflect on species, habitat, history and management of Benton Lake NWR. Follow Highway 87 north out of Great Falls about 1 mile and turn left onto Bootlegger Trail. Then go about 9 miles to the refuge entrance. The visitor center is open 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., Monday to Friday Call 406-727-7400.

35 The Annual Montana Atlatl Mammoth Hunt

Regional members of the World Atlatl Association in conjunction with First Peoples Buffalo State Park set targets along one section of the trail.
